76561198178604822.review:
[b]Overall Rating: 4/5[/b]

[b]Gameplay: 5/5 [/b]
Friday the 13th: The Game offers two distinct gameplay experiences. You can either take on the role of a counselor and work as a team to thwart Jason, or play as the iconic horror villain himself and stop the counselors before they escape. The counselor role is slightly more varied, with each character providing unique stats and styles of play (running, stealth, fighting back, focusing on objectives, etcetera). Playing as Jason is entertaining as well, with a number of different "Jasons" to pick from (each corresponding with a different film in the franchise).

The game has a lot of replayability - the variety of counselors, perks, maps and ways to play mean it doesn't get boring. With that being said, F13 is definitely more fun with friends, I'd recommend maybe buying with a group of people to play with for the best experience.

[b]Graphics and Atmosphere: 4/5[/b]
The graphics are of a good quality and the animations are generally smooth. The environment feels pretty immersive, particularly on the darker and rainy maps.

[b]Performance: 3/5[/b]
On the whole performance is decent. Occasional bugs do crop up but tend not to massively interfere with the experience. The most noticeable issue the game suffers from is a lack of players. Unfortunately the playerbase has dwindled since release and while it is possible to find matches, queue times can be long. Private matches are an option though which easily overcomes this problem if you have friends to play with.

[b]Recommendation: Worth full price.[/b]

76561198840023671.review:
The problem is that, like in the similarly structured Evolve, you can’t choose to be Jason. One player is chosen at random at the start of the match, and with up to eight players that means there is a 12.5% chance of you being Jason. You can set your preference to play Jason in the settings, but the other day I played all day long and only got to be Jason once.
So you spend the vast majority of your time as a teenager, which isn’t nearly as satisfying to play. On this side of the conflict, you have four survival options: escape by car, escape by boat, call the cops to come rescue you, or survive the night. The first three methods require finding key items in order to repair the escape route, but the items are spread across the partially randomized map randomly. There doesn’t seem to be any rhyme or reason as to how the items are distributed, so playing as a teen means just searching every drawer of every room in every cabin. That’s just not a very interesting activity, even while being hunted. The lucky jerk who gets to be Jason is out there having all the fun while you’re rummaging through desks! You can hide in an outhouse or whack Jason with a weapon to stun him, but these mostly just buy you time. There is a multistep process for actually killing Jason that is smartly tied to the movies, but it will require a lot of coordination between you and your fellow teens.
This is definitely a game where communication is key if you want to survive. The important items you need to find are so arbitrarily spread out, happening upon them all on your own is unlikely. Players on headsets will be able to let others know they’ve found the car engine, and if a couple others have the gas and keys you can all rendezvous at the escape vehicle.
While there is a lot of welcome attention to franchise details, Friday the 13th is not a polished game. In fact, it’s quite buggy. Collision detection is terrible, and it’s not uncommon to see characters popping through walls, teens hovering in the air, and corpses still flailing about after Jason has ended them. Each teen has a few lines of dialogue, but their mouths don’t move when speaking. And every single match begins with the same shot of the preppy teen’s ridiculous face, which gets old fast.

76561198307308311.review:
Playing a movie accurate Jason tends to leave a better lasting impression, and partly attributed to the effective use of stalk. An ability that allows Jason to move silently and disable the musical cue, which would otherwise alert nearby counselors to his presence. Nothing shocks unwary players more than opening a cabin door just to find Jason grabbing them by the throat.  Suddenly appearing in the middle of the road immediately sends driving players into reverse to hilarious effect. More so if the car breaks down upon collision.

Primal fear is translated quite well into gameplay mechanics. Accumulating fear decreases motor function, the loss of blood flow to the muscle causes running counselors to stumble. Whimpering while in hiding. At max level, the counselor becomes hysterical with reduced stamina regeneration and lights up like a christmas tree for Jason to see.

That being said, I had my fair share of thrilling experiences playing as counselor. Being the only remaining survivor and barely escaping by the skin of your teeth is one of its best moments. All in all, extremely suspenseful gameplay, a good visual representation of the film. Devs managed to bring Crystal lake to life for players to experience. Unfortunately there's no developer support anymore. The creators of Friday the 13th filed a lawsuit on the devs putting this game into a standstill.

76561198989937217.review:
Alright, here's the deal:

Yes, this game is a glitchy mess.
Yes, this game will crash.
Yes, this game will probably never have new content again due to legal issues.

When you look at some really cult horror, your eyes must rest on the Friday 13 series. A bloody rampage, in which a shapely lunatic with a covered face and a bunch of teenagers thinking only of sex play a role. Since its premiere in 1980, the film has had a number of sequels, TV series, books, etc. Given the immense popularity of the theme, it is surprising that the material has not seen more video game adaptations - only two. In 1989 and this year in the form of Friday the 13th: The Game, where you and other players get the main role. This is a third person survival game with asymmetric multiplayer. You probably already know that on one side there is a bloodthirsty Jason Voorhees, on the other side there are teenagers who will try to survive his rage.

[b]Jason's rampage[/b]

Asymmetric multiplayer means different abilities. Jason moves slowly, but he balances his numerical and speed disadvantages with several special abilities, the vast majority of which are very interesting, especially when you learn to use them correctly. Jason's ability to move, whether at shorter distances or anywhere on the map, helps Jason catch up.

Basically, you can be in a pretty remote place in a second, which contributes to the feeling of insurmountability of the killer character and to building tension in all survivors. As soon as Jason, even if only by chance, approaches another player, the tempo of the music changes accordingly, until a chill runs down the man's back. But back to Jason.

The other two abilities are the senses, which help Jason orient himself in dark places (something like a flashlight), or better locate his victims. All special abilities have their cooldown, in addition, they are activated gradually in the game so that the survivors have a little advantage. In addition to special abilities, Jason can also use traps and throwing knives, which slows down his victims and increases his chances of "arriving".

The killer, who controls the game well, can then play nicely with his victims. It offers the possibility to turn off the light inside the quarters, where the hidden player is currently located, you can also walk around the closet, from where the poor victim is looking at you, or you can move behind her back. This is interesting not only from the point of view of active players, but also of already deceased individuals who can observe what is happening in the same way as in other online games.

[b]Teenagers can spin it[/b]

Playing behind teenagers is a bit easier in the sense that you basically just have to hide well and press the button to hold your breath at the right time. Then, with a little luck, Jason can't locate you, and therefore can't kill you. But being hidden for long minutes and not moving is exciting so maybe for the first time. Fortunately, there are other ways to win.

First of all, you can call the police and get to them when they arrive. You can also put a car or a boat into operation, for example. That means finding a flashlight, gasoline and a key, installing and refilling everything, and then driving some distance to safety. However, you make certain sounds that Jason can pick up, so you're basically more fragile, at least if you can't handle a few basic options, such as sneaking in or hitting Jason, which stops for a few moments.

If you decide to actively fight, it is quite interesting to cooperate, however, the game has not yet balanced the cooperation. At least not as it should. Leaving aside the obligatory situation, when you get completely out of the party, a second extreme can occur. If the whole gang stays together and pounces on Jason with weapons, Jason usually won't even cross. Needless to say, the game loses its charm in such a situation.

An exception may be an extremely capable player, but I have not met that in the game yet. In addition, stronger players exaggerate a bit with godliness, so when you wait for a new sword, you have to hold out until the last seconds of the game, or jump out of the game and log in to another game. Sometimes it delays unnecessarily, but that's the fate of these online games.

[b]One on one[/b]

I must admit that the game has a relatively fast start. Without learning anything, in two games you are at the peak of your strength and you have a relatively good time. However, although the creators tried to revive it with various badges, achievements or perks that you can equip the victims with (higher running speed, higher car speed, starting the game with the first aid kit, etc.), all the magic disappears relatively quickly.

It is true that the creators operated only with a limited budget, which they collected through Kickstarter. However, it is also true that there could have been a little more possibility. A total of three maps, three main destinations, and that's it. Even the game environment is relatively austere. Except for a few weapons, items and drawers, you won't touch anything. You can only hide in the closet or under the bed. By that I mean that if you want to play this game today and every day, you will soon get into outrageous boredom. But if you turn on this game once every two years, you will have a royal fun.

It's also worth saying that we should look forward to a single-player game during the summer. However, since the game still suffers from some technical problems (for example, the trap levitates two meters from the ground, the character's teeth stick out of the mouth, as if he had no faces, etc.), the question is whether the release will not be delayed yet. In any case, the date has not yet been officially announced

Verdict:
A faithful rendition of the cult series. The entertainment is almost instant, but it also fades just as quickly. If there were more options and environments, one might last longer. But who knows. Pretty good for a few games, but you don't come back that often. The impression is spoiled by weaker graphics and technical processing.

[h1][b]6/10[/b][/h1]

I'm going to recommend this game based on overall design and game play.  The attention to detail in the maps are simply stunning!  A lot of care went into getting everything right about the main cabins and houses and very good extrapolation for the outlying areas.  

The most obvious comparison is with Dead by Daylight.  I've always felt F13 was a better designed game, especially for the counselors.  You're in better control of your own destiny and there are multiple objectives to complete an escape.  Playing as Jason requires A LOT more skill than Dead by Daylight killers because in the latter, you can accumulate perks and add ons that will do the work for you.  Every Jason has the same powers but each one does them differently.  Some better, some worse.  

What Dead by Daylight gets right is the lobbies.  Picking Jason from the public pool of players led to team killing and more trolling which helped drive away the initial player base.  Blame can be placed on the lawsuit all day if you like but looking at the data tells the real story.  The game's players declined sharply in July 2017, two months after initial release.  Not coincidentally that's when team killing began and gained a lot of traction.  Also having proximity chat as a default setting was a mistake.  Online games are filled with degenerate, hapless, maladjusted jerks that are very desperate for attention and validity.

Unfortunately with the players all but gone, what's left is the unskilled, useless trolls.   You really need 8 of your friends for a private match to actually enjoy the game.  Still, in the condition that it's in, it's still better than Dead by Daylight.

76561198035345202.review:
Friday the 13th: The Game is one of the more recognizable titles in the "asymmetric survival horror" genre that has become popular in recent years. The Friday the 13th universe is an obvious choice for a game in this genre, so obvious that there isn't the slightest need to explain why.

When you get a good lobby for the game, it's actually fun and challenging. But if you find yourself in a toxic lobby, the experience falls apart quite quickly. The ratio seems to skew in the latter direction from time to time, unfortunately. (April 2021 Update: It got worse.)

Most importantly: There seems to be an ongoing legal dispute over the game, and that has both handicapped multiplayer (public server hosting legality) and crippled ongoing development. Which is sad, really. Lawyers and entertainment industry egos really are a bunch of bastards. (April 2021 Update: It got worse.)

The game itself has become frustrating to play, and the developers more or less indicated that even if the lawsuit is (ever) settled in their favor, they're not going to have any resources to throw out this game. It's not in a good state, and it will never get better.

I tried to log in today to finish the Virtual Cabin, for the achievement and to see the franchise trivia. It seemed like a cool thing when I checked it out previously. Unfortunately I couldn't get the game to load. EAC (Easy Anti-Cheat) was apparently uninstalled on my system. I reinstalled it, and the game still crashed when starting up. I'm not going to bother trying to reinstall it from scratch, just to explore the Virtual Cabin, however cool it is.

This was a great game ruined by some bullshit. Maybe the developers can let this game go to a mod community for free, so they can run with it and see what they can come up with. Excepting that, I'm done with this game.

Rating: D-

76561198086135757.review:
Alright, I have re-written this review many times because I don't even know how I feel about it.
This is going to be a MIXED review!

Here's a pro's and con's list.

Pros:
1) The game is actually enjoyable to play! Jason and the camp counselors are fun to play, the kills are unique and each counselor has their own perks. I think my 300 hours show you how much I enjoy it.
2) The graphics are beautiful! Sure, the graphics have a few flaws, but coming from an indie game... they look really good! Is enjoyable to look and and makes the game more real and scary!
3) Each gameplay is different and challenging, what kind of game is it if it has no challenge? Every round is different and fun. The game is also very challenging which is fun.

(I'm not a big fan of the pro's list but its 12 am here for me and I'm tired, most likely gonna fix it later)

Cons:
1) Hack... lobbies... everywhere! Clicking quick play is a nightmare! Sometimes you get a real match and sometimes its a lobby with 100 players and then 50 Jasons! (Thats not how the game is meant to be played obv) I personally do not play quick play because I hate the amount hack lobbies there is. The lobbies also max out your level which give the player the feeling of no accomplishment at all. I play offline bots and sometimes private matches because quick play is a nightmare. (I have tried it today and it seems like it got worse.)
2) Peer to Peer connections. Ever since the game got sued and is now basically left to rot, the developers decided to make the lobbies peer to peer only, meaning, the connection runs off whoever the host is, which means if the host leaves, THE ENTIRE LOBBY CLOSES DOWN and kicks everyone out. Which ruins the fun.
3) The hackers in general. There are hack lobbies and straight up hackers. Cheating in Jason X or Salvini (Jason X not being out and Salvini you cant get anymore without hacking), teleporting across the map, maxed out stats even higher then Tommy Jarvis's, and making weapons huge. The Jason hackers instantly teleport to you and kill you, or even more things that I don't want to get into or this paragraph will get to long. The hackers kill the games fun
(Again wrote this at 12 am so I might re-write lmfao)


Overall, I would not buy this game unless you are okay with playing offline bots or private matches with at least 5 friends. This game has been left to rot, and there is nothing we can do about it sadly.

This game is worth buying.
I can say, with a moderate degree of certainty, that I have watched the Friday the 13th films more than any other person on the face of the earth. For the past twenty years, a week hasn’t gone by that I haven’t replayed the entire franchise at least once. The reasons for this are unimportant, but the fact of it is inarguable. I know the look and feel of the Friday films as well as it is possible to. So, it should mean something when I say that the videogame incarnation of Friday the 13th appears to have been made by people who care about the franchise almost as much as I do.

An asymmetrical multiplayer experience, Friday the 13th puts one player in the role of Jason, the mass-murdering antagonist of the titular film series. On the other side, up to seven players become the camp counselors he’s tasked with brutally dispatching. At the beginning of each match, a video plays in which Jason crashes a party in the most aggressive way imaginable, and then all of the players are scattered around the map, trying to escape while being ruthlessly hunted. They can accomplish this by repairing a vehicle and driving or boating out, by calling the police and reaching a rescue point, or by simply surviving a twenty-minute round with Jason on their heels.

…That last option is, by far, the most difficult.

While the counselors are busy looking for car batteries and gas cans, Jason has a wide variety of tools at his disposal. He can pick any random point on the map and teleport within ten meters of it, use a ‘shift’ power to zoom forward at high-speed like the POV demons from Sam Raimi’s Evil Dead films, mute the music that plays when he’s closing in on counselors so that they don’t know he’s nearby, or turn a Jason-vision power on to let him see where nearby counselors are, even through obstructions. If it sounds like Jason is overpowered, that’s because he’s supposed to be – he’s an efficient, tireless killing machine.

While there are any number of ways to delay or hurt Jason, once he’s fixated on a single counselor, it’s almost certain that they’re going to get killed. Friday the 13th‘s greatest achievement is that these deaths rarely feel unfair – yes, it can be frustrating if Jason uses his first teleport of the game to coincidentally arrive next to the cabin that a player spawned inside, but the developers have cleverly made early-round Jason weak enough for canny players to be able to outdistance him until his shift power unlocks around the two-minute mark. Although escaping is certainly satisfying, there’s plenty of satisfaction to be found in simply dodging and delaying Jason.

76561199043116506.review:
This could be a decent hide and seek game if it was not abandoned by devs.

Here's why I don't recommend this game:

1. Official dedicated servers are closed and players host game sessions. It means if the host quits the game, everyone is kicked from the session. After playing for a few hours, all of the hosts I played with left the game once they got killed. It's hard to enjoy the game like this.

2. There is no way to manage your game session. I had an opportunity to host the game for a few times and I decided not to quit and allow other players to complete the session even if that means I have to spend 15 minutes of watching others playing after I got killed. However, some players who joined my hosted session started abusing the game such as the Killer and Survivor cooperating to kill others and just messing around with the game. Since I could not remove them from my hosted game (kick or ban), I had to ask myself, do I really want to waste my time and host the game for such ***holes who don't want to play fair?

So the question is, is there any way to enjoy the game? Yes, if you have at least 4 friends who are willing to play this game in a private session. Private sessions are the only way to actually enjoy the game.

However, if you don't have many friends who are willing to play the game and you just want to enjoy the game with some other players, I do not recommend it.

76561198962241498.review:
There is a good game in Friday the 13th that pops its blood-soaked head up every now and then. Its asymmetrical teenager-versus-supernatural-murderer premise is one that will speak to anyone with an affinity for survival games, cooperative problem solving, and '80s slasher films. It has great potential, which is why you can't help but be frustrated to see it left unrealized, if not outright squandered.

A single match lasts 20 minutes, and that time will either fly by or feel twice as long depending on which role you're randomly assigned to. As a camp counselor, you are set free in one of three maps pulled from early Friday the 13th films, and are tasked with either repairing escape vehicles, calling the cops, hiding from Jason until the end of the match, or killing him--an obtuse and complex process that the game never explains, let alone hints at. If you are the lucky one who's picked at random to play Jason, your only goal is to kill every counselor that you can get your hands on.

Playing as Jason is without a doubt the most enjoyable time you'll have with Friday the 13th. As the lone killer, you are essentially unstoppable, and you gain new abilities over the course of a match that increase both your awareness and mobility. Jason can warp from one end of a camp to the other, rush across large stretches of land (think Evil Dead's encroaching force), detect fearful or active counselors, and silence the haunting theme that usually plays when he's approaching a target. He will also earn the strength to bust through doors rather than hack them open, a skill that directly thwarts a counselor's best line of defense: shelter. Playing as Jason is the epitome of a power fantasy.

76561198214899397.review:
It seems like a game about cruelty, violence and murder, but in 4 hours of playing, 6 friends were added to me, so if you have no friends, then this game is for you!
As for me, Friday is many times steeper than Dbd, the map is 5-6 times larger, there are much more opportunities to escape (call the police, go to the cars, sail away on the boat, kill Jason).
I also want to note the quite adult community, for all 4 hours of the game I met 3-4 guys who were <14 and then, these guys were quite positive and funny :)
I also liked that survivors can kill survivors, I saw such a picture, when they repaired the car, there are 4 guys waiting for it to start, then the 5th player runs out of the bushes and kills the 1st player with a gun and gets into the car instead , yes, it's mean, but in a regular game it's every man for himself!
And yes, everyone can voice chat, even Jason, but only if you are in close proximity to each other, or you have a walkie-talkie!
There are private lobbies in the game, in which you can play with friends and decide who will be Jason (in ordinary games, his role is given randomly, unless of course you have priority in your search for the survivors). I want to note that playing in a private lobby gives even more experience points than in a regular game, this is another reason to play with friends.
I would like to say a few words about the atmosphere. Everything is gloomy around, you can only hear owls and crickets, if Jason approaches you, then creepy music begins.
The game has a combat system: block, hit, dodge. Blocking really helps, but in cases where Jason is playing against you, who only waves an ax ...
There is pumping in the game, for a battle you will receive experience, it is needed to raise the level and to open perks for survivors and various finishing moves from Jason, there are really a lot of them, but on the map itself you can contact various objects, for example: you can grab survivor and kill him on the spot in 4 different ways, or throw it into the fireplace or smash his head on the door. In Dbd, the only way to kill a survivor other than Mori's mimento is by hanging from a hook.
I liked the graphon, although the game is not very optimized, when the Witcher 3 is stable at 60 fps on ultras, and Friday at 25-40, this is not normal, BUT at 30 fps it is also comfortable to play it.
There is a "fear of characters" in the game, if you see a dead ally, then you will not catch a big scrimp and your screen will turn gray, if you see Jason, then your entire screen will be black.
Jason can kill in different ways, set a trap, if the survivor gets caught, he will be slowed down. Throwing throwing knives, but there is not much sense in them, are needed in order to finish off a completely wounded survivor. Just beat with a weapon, usually 3 hits are enough and the most effective is to grab the survivor and execute him, but in this case, the survivor will have the opportunity to stab you with a knife, so you need to execute quickly.
Friday the 13th has a bunch of different characters, 1 of them have more stamina and stamina, which allows you to run faster and longer. The 2nd has more hp, the 3rd has intelligence, which makes it faster to repair.
Jason was also not spared, he also has several options from different parts of the film, the 1st has a pickaxe and the ability to carry traps, the 2nd has a spear and he can take more knives with him.

All fans of the film and fans of this genre definitely take it!
I am 100% sure that you have not read this comment to the end :)

Are you reading this as you're not really confident that this game is going fulfill your expectations? This is what I have to say.

First of all, let's make it clear: with only around 400 players at a time, this game is pretty dead. And that's probably the biggest hurdle when it comes to drawing other players to it.

However, regarding the content itself, I believe It's quite an amusing game which you'll be able to play over and over. The mechanics and tasks are as follows: 

+As a counselor, you will cooperate with other players, hide from Jason, collect weapons for self-defence, and above all, escape Camp Crystal Lake, either by finding a way to flee, or by managing to survive for 20 minutes without getting slain.

+ As Jason, your duty will be slaughtering all counselors by any means before they escape or the time runs out. To that purpose, you'll count on 4 special abilities, in addition to throwing knives and bear traps.

You might've heard no updates have been added since a lawsuit has been involved (and that's what killed this game), but its current content is more than enough to have a blast.

If you have a bunch of friends to play with, or you don't mind playing as Jason against NPCs or waiting to play with random people, then don't even hesitate to purchase it. On sale or not, you won't regret it. This game is a solid YES.

76561198013758989.review:
[h1]F13 is a Must-Play Game in a Less-than-Ideal Package[/h1]

Friday the 13th: The Game is truly something special in the gaming sphere. Flawed in many ways, marred for years by bad development and upkeep, stuck in the middle of an IP lawsuit, plagued by hackers and DDOS attacks. But still F13 remains three years in, the player base still the same as two years ago. Why did this game not just vanish into obscurity? I believe it's because it's the only asymmetrical horror game that's gotten close to the mark.

Though inundated with many ever changing bugs over the years, F13 has more or less remained a consistent experience. 7 people try to out-fight and out-wit Jason and escape the area without dying. By working together, the 7 counselors have a good shot at getting away - escaping without teamwork is a much tougher, though not impossible task. Here's where both the glory of F13 and what people consider it's worst fault come hand and hand: The toxic community.

You'll find plenty of reviews that state one the worst things in this game is the toxic community. However, I say that this is a crucial part of the magic that is F13. There is nothing more cinematic than 7 complete strangers getting dropped into a summer camp and having to survive against an extra-powerful serial killer. The best games are rooms with a few funny people, a couple jerks, a girl needing all the attention, and a Russian guy that doesn't speak English. Double points if you get a Jason that plays up the serial killer character.

The ensuing madness of the random people being gathered together, arguing and fighting, making petty alliances, betraying others, this is what makes it something else. There's nothing scary about a horror game where your team has everything fully under control - you're just doing Objective A, then B, then you win. The magic of F13 is the insane roll of the dice that is every match, the grab bag of people you get, the odds of the map items being in good spots, the poor sap that's playing Jason, the pure chaos of it all.

Now while I admit this game has the "magic" that other asymmetrical horror games are missing, don't overlook the cons that can break the game for you. To start, as the bulk of this review states, the community is nuts. You may have to play several games to get a great experience sometimes, which can be annoying when you're loading up the game to relax. I argue the thrill and entertainment from a good match shockingly balance out the frustration of lesser matches.

Another major con is the developers themselves. You don't have to [url=https://gamecrate.com/dead-again-rise-and-fall-friday-13th-game/20774]research deeply[/url] to find how dodgy and incompetent they have been with this game. Bugs have always plagued the game, and they often play into the programming trope "fix one bug, create 2 new ones". But, despite the large and various bugs over the years, they have eventually fixed nearly all of them. The con for you a player is waiting for the fix, which has left this game unplayable at times.

You'll hear people say the game has been abandoned, but if you check the [url=https://twitter.com/friday13thgame]F13TG Twitter[/url], it's never stopped being active with updates, bug fixes, new console releases, and more. The IP lawsuit over the F13 franchise has stopped content development, but they have kept the game alive despite people saying the opposite.

[b]FINAL VERDICT[/b]
F13 is a must-play game in a less than ideal package, capturing raw moments that Dead by Daylight and others are not capable of. Due to the chaotic nature of the game and it's community, players could find it disappointing at the $20 price tag at first. With persistence however, you're sure to find plenty of match experiences that make the game worth your while in the long run. At the sale price of $5-10, this game is a steal and a must have in your library.

Friday the 13th: The Game is so full of bugs, broken mechanics, and server issues that it is nearly unplayable. Half the time you launch this game, you are unable to even join a lobby no matter if you're joining a public lobby or wanting to play with your friends. Now don't get me wrong, the gameplay itself is pretty enjoyable if you're playing with a ton of your friends, but half the time you can't even experience the gameplay considering your friends won't be able to join your lobby. In my opinion, even if you can get into a lobby, it's really only fun if you're playing with a ton of your friends, and considering this game is $20 (unless it's on sale) the chances you convince enough of your friends to buy the game to even have a full lobby is possible, but unlikely.

While Friday the 13th: The Game is a pretty fun game to play if you play with all your friends, due to the fact that it's riddled with bugs, broken mechanics, and server issues, I don't recommend this game at the current prices tag of $20.

Grade: [strike] 6,5/10 [/strike] 5/10
I recommend this game to all those people who like simple survival horror games, but suggest you to get it when it's on sale or gratis (for example in Halloween's promotions). After a legal dispute, the game developers do not update Friday the 13th anymore, so don't expect any other DLC. Developers' measures against cheaters and hackers are usually insufficient (or  useless): this aspect will make the game sterile and repetitive in the long-run, if you don't coop with other players. 
So, if you want to get this game, buy it at the right time.

Edit: Some players (me included) have been blocked from hackers, so they cannot play anymore and developers probably will not intervene. After last patch of f13 (which is evidently the last one of its life), there aren't offical public servers anymore, so lobbies will behave like private sessions: if the host quits, the match is done. Due to an increasingly toxic and rogue community, it will probably become difficult to conclude a match as it should. 
Completely unsuitable quality/price ratio.
